author: philcares
content: Is the estimated tps of eth 2.0 roughly 64*tps(eth1)?

author: protolambda
content: The requirements of transactions will change towards a more stateless approach (i.e. explicit state added to transaction). At the same time, data-availability increases, so the average transaction type may also change into the direction of rollups that utilize this. And the block size and times change as well. So I don't think shard count says much.

author: philcares
content: Ok thanks for the answer. I get asked a lot what the tps of eth 2.0 will be like. As fas as I understand one cannot really tell yet since it depends on a lot of upcoming updates, correct?

author: protolambda
content: yes. And maybe you can try redirecting them to resources like the eth2.info site to learn about the design choices, if they want to understand why it's difficult to answer with a number.
